com.pump.plaf

Class FilledComboBoxUI

  • java.lang.Object
    • javax.swing.plaf.ComponentUI
      • javax.swing.plaf.ComboBoxUI
        • javax.swing.plaf.basic.BasicComboBoxUI
          • com.pump.plaf.FilledComboBoxUI

  • public class FilledComboBoxUI
extends javax.swing.plaf.basic.BasicComboBoxUI
    A BasicComboBoxUI that models its appearance after a FilledButtonUI.

    • Method Detail

      • createUI

        public static javax.swing.plaf.ComponentUI createUI(javax.swing.JComponent c)
        Create a new instance of the FilledComboBoxUI.

        Note this leaves which FilledButtonUI you want ambiguous. First this will check against the UIManager's ButtonUI property, and if that is not a FilledButtonUI then the RoundRectButtonUI will be used.

        This method is required if you want to make this ComboBoxUI the default UI by invoking:
        UIManager.getDefaults().put("ComboBoxUI", "com.pump.plaf.FilledComboBoxUI");

      • isPopDown

        protected boolean isPopDown()
        A combobox can either pop down (below the combobox), or it can pop up (or "over"). The default implementation for the BasicComboBoxUI is down, but this default implementation for this class is up. You can customize this by assigning the client property "JComboBox.isPopDown" to a Boolean.

        The following excerpt from Apple's technical note 2196 explains when to use each:

        This property alters the JComboBox's style to specify if it is intended to be a pop-down or a pop-up control. Pop-downs should be used when the user is expected to choose an action from the pop-down menu. Pop-ups should be used when the user is expected to make a choice from the pop-up menu that does not cause an action like a button would. Pop-up menus always appear over the pop-up control, whereas pop-down menus always appear below the pop-down control.

        See Also:
        Apple Tech Note 2196
